sent: Our use of cookies and similar technologies  Microsoft uses cookies and similar technologies for several purposes, depending on the context or product, including:   Storing your preferences and settings.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: This cookie allows you to move from page to page within the site without having to sign in again on each page.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You can also save your sign-in information so you do not have to sign in each time you return to the site.

sent: We use cookies to process information that helps us secure our products, as well as detect fraud and abuse.

sent: We use cookies to remember information you shared.

sent: Our use of web beacons and analytics services  Some Microsoft webpages contain electronic tags known as web beacons that we use to help deliver cookies on our websites, count users who have visited those websites, and deliver co-branded products.

Source.Name: match_377.csv

sent: Microsoft Translator processes the text, image, and voice data you submit, as well as device and usage data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: We use this data to provide Microsoft Translator, personalize your experiences, and improve our products and services.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Microsoft has implemented business and technical measures designed to help de-identify the data you submit to Microsoft Translator.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: For example, when we randomly sample text and audio to improve Microsoft Translator and Microsoft’s speech recognition technologies, we delete identifiers and certain text, such as email addresses and some number sequences, detected in the sample that could contain personal data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: To learn more about how Microsoft manages your voice data, see Speech recognition technologies.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Separate from Microsoft Translator, Microsoft translation services are available as features in other Microsoft products and services that have different privacy practices than Microsoft Translator.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: For more information on the Microsoft Azure Cognitive Services Translator Text API, Custom Translator, and Translator Speech API, see the Enterprise and developer products section of this privacy statement.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: For the Translate feature in Office apps and Skype, see the Productivity and communications products section of this privacy statement.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Top of page SwiftKeySwiftKey The Microsoft Swiftkey keyboard and related cloud-based services (collectively, the “SwiftKey Services”) process data about words you use and how you type and use this data to learn your writing style and provide personalized autocorrection and predictive text that adapts to you.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: We also use this data to offer a range of other features, such as hashtag and emoji predictions.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: SwiftKey prediction technology learns from the way you use language to build a personalized language model.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: This model is an optimized view of the words and phrases that you use most often in context and reflects your unique writing style.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: The model itself contains the words you commonly type arranged in a way that enables SwiftKey’s algorithms to make predictions, based on text you have already entered.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: The model draws from all scenarios in which you use your keyboard, including when you type while using apps or visiting websites.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: The SwiftKey keyboard and model attempt to avoid collecting sensitive data, by not collecting data from certain fields such as those recognized as containing password or payment data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: SwiftKey Services do not log, store, or learn from data you type, or the data contained in your model, unless you choose to share your data with us (as described further below).

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When you use SwiftKey Services, we also collect device and usage data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: We use de-identified device and usage data to analyze service performance and help improve our products.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: The SwiftKey Services also include an optional cloud component called a SwiftKey Account.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you choose to create a SwiftKey Account, your language model will be synced with the SwiftKey Account cloud service, so you can benefit from that model on the different devices you use and access additional services such as prediction synchronization and backup.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When you create a SwiftKey Account, Microsoft will also collect your email address and basic demographic data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: All data collected is transferred to our servers over encrypted channels.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You may also opt in to share your language, typing data, and/or voice clips for the purposes of improving Microsoft products and services.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Depending on the opt-ins you choose, SwiftKey may send short snippets of data about what and how you type and/or your voice clips, and related correction data to our servers for processing.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: These text snippets and/or voice clips are used in various automated processes to validate that our prediction services are working correctly and to make product improvements.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: To preserve your privacy, SwiftKey Services de-identify these text snippets, and even if you have a SwiftKey Account, these text snippets and/or voice clips will not be linked to it.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: To learn more about how Microsoft manages your voice data, see Speech recognition technologies.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you sign into your SwiftKey Account and opt to share your language and typing data or voice clips, Microsoft will process your shared data in order to look for new patterns of language usage across our user base.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: This allows us to improve our basic models for individual languages.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Language and typing data used in this process is aggregated and any words or combinations of words that might be personal to individuals or small groups of users are filtered out.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You can withdraw your consent to share your language and typing data or voice clips for product improvement at any time in SwiftKey Settings.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You can also withdraw your consent for SwiftKey Services to retain your personal data in SwiftKey Settings.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When you withdraw consent for SwiftKey to retain your personal data, all personal data collected through your use of the SwiftKey Services will be deleted.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You may receive occasional notifications on your device alerting you to product updates and features that may be of interest to you.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You can disable these notifications at any time in the SwiftKey Settings.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Top of page WindowsWindowsWindows is a personalized computing environment that enables you to seamlessly roam and access services, preferences, and content across your computing devices from phones to tablets to the Surface Hub.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Rather than residing as a static software program on your device, key components of Windows are cloud-based, and both cloud and local elements of Windows are updated regularly, providing you with the latest improvements and features.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: In order to provide this computing experience, we collect data about you, your device, and the way you use Windows.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: And because Windows is personal to you, we give you choices about the personal data we collect and how we use it.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Note that if your Windows device is managed by your organization (such as your employer or school), your organization may use centralized management tools provided by Microsoft or others to access and process your data and to control device settings (including privacy settings), device policies, software updates, data collection by us or the organization, or other aspects of your device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Additionally, your organization may use management tools provided by Microsoft or others to access and process your data from that device, including your interaction data, diagnostic data, and the contents of your communications and files.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: For more information about data collection and privacy in Windows, see Windows 10 and your online services.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Earlier versions of Windows (including Windows Vista, Windows 7, Windows 8, and Windows 8.1) are subject to their own privacy statements.Learn moreTop of page ActivationActivationWhen you activate Windows, a specific product key is associated with the device on which your software is installed.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: The product key and data about the software and your device is sent to Microsoft to help validate your license to the software.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: This data may be sent again if there is a need to re-activate or validate your license.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: On phones running Windows, device and network identifiers, as well as device location at the time of the first power-up of the device, are also sent to Microsoft for the purpose of warranty registration, stock replenishment, and fraud prevention.Top of page Activity historyActivity historyActivity history helps keep track of the things you do on your device, such as the apps and services you use, the files you open, and the websites you browse.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Your activity history is stored locally on your device when using different apps and features such as Microsoft Edge, some Microsoft Store apps, and Microsoft 365 apps.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you've signed in to your device with a Microsoft account and given your permission, Windows sends your activity history to Microsoft.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Once your activity history is in the cloud, Microsoft uses that data to enable cross-device experiences, to provide you with the ability to continue those activities on other devices, to provide personalized experiences (such as ordering your activities based on duration of use) and relevant suggestions (such as anticipating what your needs might be based on your activity history), and to help improve Microsoft products.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Activity history is also created and sent to Microsoft when you use Microsoft apps, such as Microsoft Edge, and Office apps like Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, on mobile devices such as iOS and Android phones and tablets.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you are signed in with your Microsoft account, you can continue activities on your Windows 10 device that you started in Microsoft apps on your Android or iOS device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You can turn settings off or on for sending your activity history to Microsoft and storing activity history locally on your device, and you can also clear your device’s activity history at any time by going to Start &gt.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Learn more about activity history in Windows 10.Top of page Advertising IDAdvertising IDWindows generates a unique advertising ID for each person using a device, which app developers and advertising networks can then use for their own purposes, including providing relevant advertising in apps.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When the advertising ID is enabled, both Microsoft apps and third-party apps can access and use the advertising ID in much the same way that websites can access and use a unique identifier stored in a cookie.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Thus, your advertising ID can be used by app developers and advertising networks to provide more relevant advertising and other personalized experiences across their apps and on the web.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Microsoft collects the advertising ID for the uses described here only when you choose to enable the advertising ID as part of your privacy setting.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: The advertising ID setting applies to Windows apps using the Windows advertising identifier.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You can turn off access to this identifier at any time by turning off the advertising ID in Settings.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you choose to turn it on again, the advertising ID will be reset and a new identifier will be generated.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When a third-party app accesses the advertising ID, its use of the advertising ID will be subject to its own privacy policy.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Learn more about advertising ID in Windows 10.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: The advertising ID setting does not apply to other methods of interest-based advertising delivered by Microsoft or third parties, such as cookies used to provide interest-based display ads on websites.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Third-party products accessed through or installed on Windows may also deliver other forms of interest-based advertising subject to their own privacy policies.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Microsoft delivers other forms of interest-based ads in certain Microsoft products, both directly and by partnering with third-party ad providers.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: For more information on how Microsoft uses data for advertising, see the How we use personal data section of this statement.Top of page DiagnosticsDiagnosticsMicrosoft collects Windows diagnostic data to solve problems and to keep Windows up to date, secure, and operating properly.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: It also helps us improve Windows and related Microsoft products and services and, for customers who have turned on the “Tailored experiences” setting, to provide more relevant tips and recommendations to tailor Microsoft and third-party products and services for Windows to the customer’s needs.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: This data is transmitted to Microsoft and stored with one or more unique identifiers that can help us recognize an individual user on an individual device and understand the device's service issues and use patterns.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: There are two levels of diagnostic and activity data: Required diagnostic data and Optional diagnostic data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Certain product documentation and other materials refer to Required diagnostic data as Basic diagnostic data and to Optional diagnostic data as Full diagnostic data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If an organization (such as your employer or school) uses Microsoft management tools or engages Microsoft to manage your device, we and the organization will use and process diagnostic and error data from your device to allow the management, monitoring, and troubleshooting of the organization's devices, and for other purposes of the organization.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Required diagnostic data includes information about your device, its settings and capabilities, and whether it is performing properly.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: We collect the following Required diagnostic data:   Device, connectivity, and configuration data:  Data about the device such as the processor type, OEM manufacturer, type of battery and capacity, number and type of cameras, firmware, and memory attributes.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Network capabilities and connection data such as the device’s IP address, mobile network (including IMEI and mobile operator), and whether the device is connected to a free or paid network.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Data about the operating system and its configuration such as the OS version and build number, region and language settings, diagnostics data settings, and whether the device is part of the Windows Insider program.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Data about connected peripherals such as model, manufacturer, drivers, and compatibility data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Data about the applications installed on the device such as application name, version, and publisher.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Whether a device is ready for an update and whether there are factors that may impede the ability to receive updates, such as low battery, limited disk space, or connectivity through a paid network.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Whether updates complete successfully or fail.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Data about the reliability of the diagnostics collection system itself.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Basic error reporting, which is health data about the operating system and applications running on your device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: For example, basic error reporting tells us if an application, such as Microsoft Paint or a third-party game, hangs or crashes.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Optional diagnostic data includes more detailed information about your device and its settings, capabilities, and device health.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Optional diagnostic data also includes data about the websites you browse, device activity (also sometimes referred to as usage), and enhanced error reporting that helps Microsoft to fix and improve products and services for all users.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When you choose to send Optional diagnostic data, Required diagnostic data will always be included, and we collect the following additional information:  Additional data about the device, connectivity, and configuration, beyond that collected under Required diagnostic data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Status and logging information about the health of operating system and other system components beyond that collected about the update and diagnostics systems under Required diagnostic data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: App activity, such as which programs are launched on a device, how long they run, and how quickly they respond to input.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Browser activity, including browsing history and search terms, in Microsoft browsers (Microsoft Edge or Internet Explorer).

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Enhanced error reporting, including the memory state of the device when a system or app crash occurs (which may unintentionally contain user content, such as parts of a file you were using when the problem occurred).

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Crash data is never used for Tailored experiences as described below.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Some of the data described above may not be collected from your device even if you choose to send Optional diagnostic data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Microsoft minimizes the volume of Optional diagnostic data it collects from all devices by collecting some of the data from only a subset of devices (sample).

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: By running the Diagnostic Data Viewer tool, you can see an icon which indicates whether your device is part of a sample and also which specific data is collected from your device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Instructions for how to download the Diagnostic Data Viewer tool can be found at Start &gt.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Specific data items collected in Windows diagnostics are subject to change to give Microsoft flexibility to collect the data needed for the purposes described.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: For example, to ensure Microsoft can troubleshoot the latest performance issue impacting users’ computing experience or update a Windows 10 device that is new to the market, Microsoft may need to collect data items that were not collected previously.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: For a current list of data types collected at Required diagnostic data and Optional diagnostic data, see Windows Required (Basic level) diagnostic events and fields or Windows 10 Optional (Full level) diagnostic data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: We provide limited portions of error report information to partners (such as the device manufacturer) to help them troubleshoot products and services which work with Windows and other Microsoft product and services.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: They are only permitted to use this information to repair or improve those products and services.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: It also includes sharing data, when it is required to provide the service or carry out the transactions you request.
point_text: Microsoft uses the data we collect to provide you rich, interactive experiences. In particular, we use data to:  Provide our products, which includes updating, securing, and troubleshooting, as well as providing support. It also includes sharing data, when it is required to provide the service or carry out the transactions you request. Improve and develop our products. Personalize our products and make recommendations. Advertise and market to you, which includes sending promotional communications, targeting advertising, and presenting you relevant offers.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Learn more about diagnostic data in Windows 10.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You also can choose to help Microsoft improve inking and typing recognition by sending inking and typing diagnostic data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you choose to do so, Microsoft will collect samples of the content you type or write to improve features such as handwriting recognition, autocompletion, next word prediction, and spelling correction in the many languages used by Windows customers.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When Microsoft collects inking and typing diagnostic data, it is divided into small samples and processed to remove unique identifiers, sequencing information, and other data (such as email addresses and numeric values) which could be used to reconstruct the original content or associate the input to you.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: It also includes associated performance data, such as changes you manually make to text, as well as words you've added to the dictionary.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Learn more about improving inking and typing in Windows 10.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you choose to turn on Tailored experiences, we will use your Windows diagnostic data (Basic or Full as you have selected) to offer you personalized tips, ads, and recommendations to enhance Microsoft experiences.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you have selected Basic as your diagnostic data setting, personalization is based on information about your device, its settings and capabilities, and whether it is performing properly.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you have selected Full, personalization is also based on information about how you use apps and features, plus additional information about the health of your device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: However, we do not use information about the websites you browse, the content of crash dumps, speech, typing, or inking input data for personalization when we receive such data from customers who have selected Full.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Tailored experiences include suggestions on how to customize and optimize Windows, as well as ads and recommendations for Microsoft and third-party products and services, features, apps, and hardware for your Windows experiences.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: For example, to help you get the most out of your device, we may tell you about features you may not know about or that are new.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you are having a problem with your Windows device, you may be offered a solution.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You may be offered a chance to customize your lock screen with pictures, or to be shown more pictures of the kind you like, or fewer of the ones you don’t.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you stream movies in your browser, you may be recommended an app from the Microsoft Store that streams more efficiently.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Or, if you are running out of space on your hard drive, Windows may recommend you try OneDrive or purchase hardware to gain more space.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Learn more about tailored experiences in Windows 10.Top of page Feedback HubFeedback HubFeedback Hub is a preinstalled app that provides a way to gather feedback on Microsoft products and installed first party and third-party apps.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You can sign into Feedback Hub using either your personal Microsoft account or an account provided by your organization (such as your employer or school) that you use to sign into Microsoft products.

sent: Signing in with your work or school account allows you to submit feedback to Microsoft in association with your organization.

sent: Additionally, if feedback is provided using your work or school account, your feedback can be viewed through the Feedback Hub by your organization’s administrators.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When you submit feedback to Microsoft about a problem or add more details to a problem, diagnostic data will be sent to Microsoft to improve Microsoft products and services.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Depending on your Diagnostic data settings in Start &gt.

sent: feedback, Feedback Hub will either send diagnostic data automatically or you will have the option to send it to Microsoft at the time you provide feedback.

sent: Microsoft may also share your feedback along with the data collected when you submit your feedback with Microsoft partners (such as a device manufacturer, or firmware developer) to help them troubleshoot products and services that work with Windows and other Microsoft products and services.

sent: Learn more about diagnostic data in Windows 10.Top of page Location services, motion sensing, and recordingLocation services, motion sensing, and recording Windows location service.

sent: Microsoft operates a location service that helps determine the precise geographic location of a specific Windows device.

sent: Depending on the capabilities of the device, the device’s location can be determined with varying degrees of accuracy and may in some cases be determined precisely.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When you have enabled location on a Windows device, or you have given permission for Microsoft apps to access location information on non-Windows devices, data about cell towers and Wi-Fi access points and their locations is collected by Microsoft and added to the location database after removing any data identifying the person or device from which it was collected.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: This de-identified copy of location information is used to improve Microsoft's location services and, in some instances, shared with our location service provider partners, currently HERE (see https://www.here.com/), to improve the location services of the provider.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Windows services and features (such as browsers and Cortana), apps running on Windows, and websites opened in Windows browsers can access the device’s location through Windows if your settings allow them to do so.

It also includes sharing data, when it is required to provide the service or carry out the transactions you request. Improve and develop our products. Personalize our products and make recommendations. Advertise and market to you, which includes sending promotional communications, targeting advertising, and presenting you relevant offers.

sent: Our use of cookies and similar technologies  Microsoft uses cookies and similar technologies for several purposes, depending on the context or product, including:   Storing your preferences and settings.

sent: You can also save your sign-in information so you do not have to sign in each time you return to the site.

Microsoft uses the data we collect to provide you rich, interactive experiences. In particular, we use data to:  Provide our products, which includes updating, securing, and troubleshooting, as well as providing support. It also includes sharing data, when it is required to provide the service or carry out the transactions you request. Improve and develop our products. We also use the data to operate our business, which includes analyzing our performance, meeting our legal obligations, developing our workforce, and doing research.
        
Microsoft uses the data we collect to provide you rich, interactive experiences. In particular, we use data to:  Provide our products, which includes updating, securing, and troubleshooting, as well as providing support. It also includes sharing data, when it is required to provide the service or carry out the transactions you request. Improve and develop our products. Personalize our products and make recommendations. Advertise and market to you, which includes sending promotional communications, targeting advertising, and presenting you relevant offers.  We also use the data to operate our business, which includes analyzing our performance, meeting our legal obligations, developing our workforce, and doing research

point_text:
We also use the data to operate our business, which includes analyzing our performance, meeting our legal obligations, developing our workforce, and doing research.
        
Microsoft uses the data we collect to provide you rich, interactive experiences. In particular, we use data to:  Provide our products, which includes updating, securing, and troubleshooting, as well as providing support. It also includes sharing data, when it is required to provide the service or carry out the transactions you request. Improve and develop our products. Personalize our products and make recommendations. Advertise and market to you, which includes sending promotional communications, targeting advertising, and presenting you relevant offers.  We also use the data to operate our business, which includes analyzing our performance, meeting our legal obligations, developing our workforce, and doing research

sent: SwiftKeySwiftKeymainswiftkeymoduleSummary The Microsoft Swiftkey keyboard and related cloud-based services (collectively, the “SwiftKey Services”) process data about words you use and how you type and use this data to learn your writing style and provide personalized autocorrection and predictive text that adapts to you.

sent: We also use this data to offer a range of other features, such as hashtag and emoji predictions.

Source.Name: match_377.csv

sent: This model is an optimized view of the words and phrases that you use most often in context and reflects your unique writing style.

sent: Note that if your Windows device is managed by your organization (such as your employer or school), your organization may use centralized management tools provided by Microsoft or others to access and process your data and to control device settings (including privacy settings), device policies, software updates, data collection by us or the organization, or other aspects of your device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Additionally, your organization may use management tools provided by Microsoft or others to access and process your data from that device, including your interaction data, diagnostic data, and the contents of your communications and files.

sent: Earlier versions of Windows (including Windows Vista, Windows 7, Windows 8, and Windows 8.1) are subject to their own privacy statements.ActivationActivationmainactivationmoduleSummaryWhen you activate Windows, a specific product key is associated with the device on which your software is installed.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: On phones running Windows, device and network identifiers, as well as device location at the time of the first power-up of the device, are also sent to Microsoft for the purpose of warranty registration, stock replenishment, and fraud prevention.Activity historyActivity historymainactivityhistorymoduleSummaryActivity history helps keep track of the things you do on your device, such as the apps and services you use, the files you open, and the websites you browse.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Your activity history is stored locally on your device when using different apps and features such as Microsoft Edge, some Microsoft Store apps, and Microsoft 365 apps.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you've signed in to your device with a Microsoft account and given your permission, Windows sends your activity history to Microsoft.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Once your activity history is in the cloud, Microsoft uses that data to enable cross-device experiences, to provide you with the ability to continue those activities on other devices, to provide personalized experiences (such as ordering your activities based on duration of use) and relevant suggestions (such as anticipating what your needs might be based on your activity history), and to help improve Microsoft products.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Activity history is also created and sent to Microsoft when you use Microsoft apps, such as Microsoft Edge, and Office apps like Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, on mobile devices such as iOS and Android phones and tablets.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you are signed in with your Microsoft account, you can continue activities on your Windows 10 device that you started in Microsoft apps on your Android or iOS device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You can turn settings off or on for sending your activity history to Microsoft and storing activity history locally on your device, and you can also clear your device’s activity history at any time by going to Start &gt.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Learn more about activity history in Windows 10.Advertising IDAdvertising IDmainadvertisingidmoduleSummaryWindows generates a unique advertising ID for each person using a device, which app developers and advertising networks can then use for their own purposes, including providing relevant advertising in apps.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When the advertising ID is enabled, both Microsoft apps and third-party apps can access and use the advertising ID in much the same way that websites can access and use a unique identifier stored in a cookie.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Thus, your advertising ID can be used by app developers and advertising networks to provide more relevant advertising and other personalized experiences across their apps and on the web.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Microsoft collects the advertising ID for the uses described here only when you choose to enable the advertising ID as part of your privacy setting.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: The advertising ID setting applies to Windows apps using the Windows advertising identifier.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You can turn off access to this identifier at any time by turning off the advertising ID in Settings.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you choose to turn it on again, the advertising ID will be reset and a new identifier will be generated.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When a third-party app accesses the advertising ID, its use of the advertising ID will be subject to its own privacy policy.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Learn more about advertising ID in Windows 10.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: The advertising ID setting does not apply to other methods of interest-based advertising delivered by Microsoft or third parties, such as cookies used to provide interest-based display ads on websites.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Third-party products accessed through or installed on Windows may also deliver other forms of interest-based advertising subject to their own privacy policies.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Microsoft delivers other forms of interest-based ads in certain Microsoft products, both directly and by partnering with third-party ad providers.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: For more information on how Microsoft uses data for advertising, see the How we use personal data section of this statement.DiagnosticsDiagnosticsmaindiagnosticsmoduleSummaryMicrosoft collects Windows diagnostic data to solve problems and to keep Windows up to date, secure, and operating properly.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: It also helps us improve Windows and related Microsoft products and services and, for customers who have turned on the “Tailored experiences” setting, to provide more relevant tips and recommendations to tailor Microsoft and third-party products and services for Windows to the customer’s needs.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: This data is transmitted to Microsoft and stored with one or more unique identifiers that can help us recognize an individual user on an individual device and understand the device's service issues and use patterns.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: There are two levels of diagnostic and activity data: Required diagnostic data and Optional diagnostic data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Certain product documentation and other materials refer to Required diagnostic data as Basic diagnostic data and to Optional diagnostic data as Full diagnostic data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If an organization (such as your employer or school) uses Microsoft management tools or engages Microsoft to manage your device, we and the organization will use and process diagnostic and error data from your device to allow the management, monitoring, and troubleshooting of the organization's devices, and for other purposes of the organization.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Required diagnostic data includes information about your device, its settings and capabilities, and whether it is performing properly.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: We collect the following Required diagnostic data:   Device, connectivity, and configuration data:  Data about the device such as the processor type, OEM manufacturer, type of battery and capacity, number and type of cameras, firmware, and memory attributes.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Network capabilities and connection data such as the device’s IP address, mobile network (including IMEI and mobile operator), and whether the device is connected to a free or paid network.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Data about the operating system and its configuration such as the OS version and build number, region and language settings, diagnostics data settings, and whether the device is part of the Windows Insider program.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Data about connected peripherals such as model, manufacturer, drivers, and compatibility data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Data about the applications installed on the device such as application name, version, and publisher.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Whether a device is ready for an update and whether there are factors that may impede the ability to receive updates, such as low battery, limited disk space, or connectivity through a paid network.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Whether updates complete successfully or fail.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Data about the reliability of the diagnostics collection system itself.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Basic error reporting, which is health data about the operating system and applications running on your device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: For example, basic error reporting tells us if an application, such as Microsoft Paint or a third-party game, hangs or crashes.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Optional diagnostic data includes more detailed information about your device and its settings, capabilities, and device health.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Optional diagnostic data also includes data about the websites you browse, device activity (also sometimes referred to as usage), and enhanced error reporting that helps Microsoft to fix and improve products and services for all users.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When you choose to send Optional diagnostic data, Required diagnostic data will always be included, and we collect the following additional information:  Additional data about the device, connectivity, and configuration, beyond that collected under Required diagnostic data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Status and logging information about the health of operating system and other system components beyond that collected about the update and diagnostics systems under Required diagnostic data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: App activity, such as which programs are launched on a device, how long they run, and how quickly they respond to input.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Browser activity, including browsing history and search terms, in Microsoft browsers (Microsoft Edge or Internet Explorer).

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Enhanced error reporting, including the memory state of the device when a system or app crash occurs (which may unintentionally contain user content, such as parts of a file you were using when the problem occurred).

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Crash data is never used for Tailored experiences as described below.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Some of the data described above may not be collected from your device even if you choose to send Optional diagnostic data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Microsoft minimizes the volume of Optional diagnostic data it collects from all devices by collecting some of the data from only a subset of devices (sample).

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: By running the Diagnostic Data Viewer tool, you can see an icon which indicates whether your device is part of a sample and also which specific data is collected from your device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Instructions for how to download the Diagnostic Data Viewer tool can be found at Start &gt.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Specific data items collected in Windows diagnostics are subject to change to give Microsoft flexibility to collect the data needed for the purposes described.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: For example, to ensure Microsoft can troubleshoot the latest performance issue impacting users’ computing experience or update a Windows 10 device that is new to the market, Microsoft may need to collect data items that were not collected previously.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: For a current list of data types collected at Required diagnostic data and Optional diagnostic data, see Windows Required (Basic level) diagnostic events and fields or Windows 10 Optional (Full level) diagnostic data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: We provide limited portions of error report information to partners (such as the device manufacturer) to help them troubleshoot products and services which work with Windows and other Microsoft product and services.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: They are only permitted to use this information to repair or improve those products and services.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When your child uses an Xbox online game or any network-connected app on their Xbox console, PC, or mobile device, the publisher of that game or app has access to data about their usage to help the publisher deliver, support, and improve its product.
point_text: When your child uses an Xbox online game or any network-connected app on their Xbox console, PC, or mobile device, the publisher of that game or app has access to data about their usage to help the publisher deliver, support, and improve its product.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Learn more about diagnostic data in Windows 10.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You also can choose to help Microsoft improve inking and typing recognition by sending inking and typing diagnostic data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you choose to do so, Microsoft will collect samples of the content you type or write to improve features such as handwriting recognition, autocompletion, next word prediction, and spelling correction in the many languages used by Windows customers.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When Microsoft collects inking and typing diagnostic data, it is divided into small samples and processed to remove unique identifiers, sequencing information, and other data (such as email addresses and numeric values) which could be used to reconstruct the original content or associate the input to you.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: It also includes associated performance data, such as changes you manually make to text, as well as words you've added to the dictionary.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Learn more about improving inking and typing in Windows 10.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you choose to turn on Tailored experiences, we will use your Windows diagnostic data (Basic or Full as you have selected) to offer you personalized tips, ads, and recommendations to enhance Microsoft experiences.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you have selected Basic as your diagnostic data setting, personalization is based on information about your device, its settings and capabilities, and whether it is performing properly.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you have selected Full, personalization is also based on information about how you use apps and features, plus additional information about the health of your device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: However, we do not use information about the websites you browse, the content of crash dumps, speech, typing, or inking input data for personalization when we receive such data from customers who have selected Full.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Tailored experiences include suggestions on how to customize and optimize Windows, as well as ads and recommendations for Microsoft and third-party products and services, features, apps, and hardware for your Windows experiences.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: For example, to help you get the most out of your device, we may tell you about features you may not know about or that are new.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you are having a problem with your Windows device, you may be offered a solution.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You may be offered a chance to customize your lock screen with pictures, or to be shown more pictures of the kind you like, or fewer of the ones you don’t.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you stream movies in your browser, you may be recommended an app from the Microsoft Store that streams more efficiently.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Or, if you are running out of space on your hard drive, Windows may recommend you try OneDrive or purchase hardware to gain more space.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Learn more about tailored experiences in Windows 10.Feedback HubFeedback HubmainfeedbackhubmoduleSummaryFeedback Hub is a preinstalled app that provides a way to gather feedback on Microsoft products and installed first party and third-party apps.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You can sign into Feedback Hub using either your personal Microsoft account or an account provided by your organization (such as your employer or school) that you use to sign into Microsoft products.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Signing in with your work or school account allows you to submit feedback to Microsoft in association with your organization.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Any feedback you provide whether using your work or school account or personal Microsoft account may be publicly viewable depending on the settings configured by your organization’s administrators.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Additionally, if feedback is provided using your work or school account, your feedback can be viewed through the Feedback Hub by your organization’s administrators.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When you submit feedback to Microsoft about a problem or add more details to a problem, diagnostic data will be sent to Microsoft to improve Microsoft products and services.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Depending on your Diagnostic data settings in Start &gt.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: feedback, Feedback Hub will either send diagnostic data automatically or you will have the option to send it to Microsoft at the time you provide feedback.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Based on the category chosen when submitting feedback, there may be additional personal data collected that helps to further troubleshoot issues.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: for example, location related information when submitting feedback about location services or gaze related information when submitting feedback on Mixed Reality.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Microsoft may also share your feedback along with the data collected when you submit your feedback with Microsoft partners (such as a device manufacturer, or firmware developer) to help them troubleshoot products and services that work with Windows and other Microsoft products and services.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Learn more about diagnostic data in Windows 10.Location services, motion sensing, and recordingLocation services, motion sensing, and recordingmainlocationservicesmotionsensingmoduleSummary Windows location service.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Microsoft operates a location service that helps determine the precise geographic location of a specific Windows device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Depending on the capabilities of the device, the device’s location can be determined with varying degrees of accuracy and may in some cases be determined precisely.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When you have enabled location on a Windows device, or you have given permission for Microsoft apps to access location information on non-Windows devices, data about cell towers and Wi-Fi access points and their locations is collected by Microsoft and added to the location database after removing any data identifying the person or device from which it was collected.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: This de-identified copy of location information is used to improve Microsoft's location services and, in some instances, shared with our location service provider partners, currently HERE (see https://www.here.com/), to improve the location services of the provider.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Windows services and features (such as browsers and Cortana), apps running on Windows, and websites opened in Windows browsers can access the device’s location through Windows if your settings allow them to do so.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Some features and apps request location permission when you first install Windows, some ask the first time you use the app, and others ask every time you access the device’s location.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: For information about certain Windows apps that use the device’s location, see the Windows apps section of this privacy statement.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When an app or feature accesses the device’s location and you are signed in with a Microsoft account, your Windows device will also upload its location to the cloud where it is available across your devices to other apps or services that use your Microsoft account and for which you’ve granted permission.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: We will retain only the last known location (each new location replaces the previous one).

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Data about a Windows device's recent location history is also stored on the device even if not using a Microsoft account, and certain apps and Windows features can access this location history.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You can clear your device's location history at any time in the device's Settings menu.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: In Settings, you can also view which apps have access to the device’s precise location or your device's location history, turn off or on access to the device’s location for particular apps, or turn off access to the device’s location.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You can also set a default location, which will be used when the location service can’t detect a more exact location for your device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Even when you’ve turned off access to the device’s location, some third-party desktop apps and services could use other technologies (such as Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, cellular modem, etc.)

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: to determine the device’s precise location.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Learn more about third-party desktop apps and how they may still be able to determine your device’s location when the device’s location setting is off.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: In addition, to facilitate getting help in an emergency, whenever you make an emergency call, Windows will attempt to determine and share your precise location, regardless of your location settings.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If your device has a SIM card or is otherwise using cellular service, your mobile operator will have access to your device’s location.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Learn more about location in Windows 10.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you turn on the General Location feature, apps that cannot use your precise location will have access to your general location, such as your city, postal code, or region.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: The Find My Phone feature allows you to find the location of your Windows phone from the Microsoft account website, even if you have turned off all access to the location service on the phone.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: "If you have turned on the ""save my location every few hours"" feature in the Find My Phone settings on your phone, the Find My Phone feature will periodically send and store a single last-known location of your phone, even if you have turned off location services on your phone."

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Each time a new location is sent, it replaces the previously-stored location.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: The Find my device feature allows an administrator of a Windows portable device to find the location of that device from account.microsoft.com/devices.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: To enable Find my device, an administrator needs to be signed in with a Microsoft account and have the location setting enabled.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: This feature will work even if other users have denied access to location for all their apps.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When the administrator attempts to locate the device, users will see a notification in the notification area.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Learn more about Find my device in Windows 10.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Windows devices with motion activity detection can collect motion activity.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: This data can enable features such as a pedometer to count the number of steps you take, so a fitness application can estimate how many calories you burn.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: This data and history is stored on your device and can be accessed by applications you give permission to access and use that data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Some Windows devices have a recording feature that allows you to capture audio and video clips of your activity on the device, including your communications with others.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you choose to record a session, the recording will be saved locally on your device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: In some cases, you may have the option to transmit the recording to a Microsoft product or service that broadcasts the recording publicly.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Important: You should understand your legal responsibilities before recording and/or transmitting any communication.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: This may include obtaining the prior consent of everyone participating in the conversation or any other authorizations as required.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Microsoft is not responsible for how you use recording features or your recordings.Security and safety featuresSecurity and safety featuresmainsecurityandsafetyfeaturesmoduleSummary Device encryption.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Device encryption helps protect the data stored on your device by encrypting it using BitLocker Drive Encryption technology.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When device encryption is on, Windows automatically encrypts the drive Windows is installed on and generates a recovery key.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: The BitLocker recovery key for your personal device is automatically backed up online in your personal Microsoft OneDrive account.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Microsoft doesn't use your individual recovery keys for any purpose.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: The Malicious Software Removal Tool (MSRT) runs on your device at least once per month as part of Windows Update.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: "MSRT checks devices for infections by specific, prevalent malicious software (""malware"") and helps remove any infections found."

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When the MSRT runs, it will remove the malware listed on the Microsoft Support website if the malware is on your device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: During a malware check, a report will be sent to Microsoft with specific data about malware detected, errors, and other data about your device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you do not want MSRT to send this data to Microsoft, you can disable MSRT's reporting component.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Parents can use Microsoft Family to understand and set boundaries on how their child is using their device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: There are many features available to Family members, so please carefully review the information provided when you create or join a Family.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When Family activity reporting is turned on for a child, Microsoft will collect details about how the child uses their device and provide parents with reports of that child's activities.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Activity reports are routinely deleted from Microsoft servers after a short period of time.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Microsoft Defender SmartScreen helps protect you when using our services by checking downloaded files and web content for malicious software, potentially unsafe web content, and other threats to you or your device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When checking a file, data about that file is sent to Microsoft, including the file name, a hash of the file's contents, the download location, and the file's digital certificates.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If Microsoft Defender SmartScreen identifies the file as unknown or potentially unsafe, you will see a warning prior to opening the file.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When checking web content, data about the content and your device is sent to Microsoft, including the full web address of the content.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If Microsoft Defender SmartScreen detects that content is potentially unsafe, you will see a warning in place of the content.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Microsoft Defender SmartScreen can be turned on or off in Settings.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Microsoft Defender Antivirus looks for malware and other unwanted software, potentially unwanted apps, and other malicious content on your device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Microsoft Defender Antivirus is automatically turned on to help protect your device if no other antimalware software is actively protecting your device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If Microsoft Defender Antivirus is turned on, it will monitor the security status of your device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When Microsoft Defender Antivirus is turned on, or is running because Limited Periodic Scanning is enabled, it will automatically send reports to Microsoft that contain data about suspected malware and other unwanted software, potentially unwanted apps, and other malicious content, and it may also send files that could contain malicious content, such as malware or unknown files for further inspection.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If a report is likely to contain personal data, the report is not sent automatically, and you'll be prompted before it is sent.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You can configure Microsoft Defender Antivirus not to send reports and suspected malware to Microsoft.Speech, Voice Activation, Inking, and TypingSpeech, Voice Activation, Inking, and TypingmainspeechinkingtypingmoduleSummary Speech.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Microsoft provides both a device-based speech recognition feature and cloud-based (online) speech recognition technologies.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Turning on the online speech recognition setting lets you use Microsoft’s cloud-based speech recognition technologies in Cortana, the Mixed Reality Portal, dictation in Windows, supported Microsoft Store apps, and over time in other parts of Windows.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Turning on speech while setting up a HoloLens device or installing Windows Mixed Reality allows you to use your voice for commands, dictation, and app interactions.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Both device-based speech recognition and online speech recognition settings will be enabled.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: With both settings enabled, while your headset is turned on the device will always be listening to your voice input and will send your voice data to Microsoft’s cloud-based speech recognition technologies.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When you use Microsoft’s cloud-based speech recognition technologies, Microsoft collects and uses your voice recordings to create a text transcription of the spoken words in the voice data.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: To learn more about how Microsoft manages your voice data, see Speech recognition technologies.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You can use device-based speech recognition without sending your voice data to Microsoft.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: However, Microsoft’s cloud-based speech recognition technologies provide more accurate recognition than the device-based speech recognition.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When the online speech recognition setting is turned off, speech services that don’t rely on the cloud and only use device-based recognition—like the Narrator app or the Windows Speech Recognition app—will still work.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you’ve given permission in Cortana, we also collect additional information, like your name and nickname, your recent calendar events, and the names of the people in your appointments, information about your contacts including names and nicknames, names of your favorite places, apps you use, and information about your music preferences.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: This additional data enables us to better recognize people, events, places, and music when you dictate commands, messages, or documents.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You can turn off online speech recognition at any time.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: This will stop your voice data from being sent to Microsoft.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you are using a HoloLens or mixed reality headset, you can also turn off device-based speech recognition at any time.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: This will stop the device from listening for your voice input.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Learn more about speech recognition in Windows 10.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Windows provides supported apps with the ability to respond and take action based on voice keywords that are specific to that app—for example allowing Cortana to listen and respond to “Hey Cortana.”  If you’ve given permission for an app to listen for voice keywords, Windows 10 will be actively listening to the microphone for these keywords.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Once a keyword is recognized, the app will have access to your voice recording, can process the recording, take action, and respond, such as with a spoken answer.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: The app may send the voice recording to its own services in the cloud to process the commands.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Each app should ask you for permission before accessing voice recordings.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Additionally, voice activation can be enabled when the device is locked.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If enabled, the relevant app will continue listening to the microphone for voice keywords when you have locked your device and can activate for anyone who speaks near the device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When the device is locked, the app will have access to the same set of capabilities and information as when the device is unlocked.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: You can turn off voice activation at any time.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Learn more about voice activation in Windows 10.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Even when you’ve turned off voice activation, some third-party desktop apps and services could still be listening to the microphone and collect your voice input.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: Learn more about third-party desktop apps and how they may still be able to access your microphone even with these settings turned off.

Source.Name: match_377.csv

sent: Silverlight uses Microsoft Digital Rights Management (DRM) technology to help protect the rights of content owners.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: If you access DRM-protected content (such as music or video) with Silverlight, it will request media usage rights from a rights server on the Internet.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: In order to provide a seamless playback experience, you will not be prompted before Silverlight sends the request to the rights server.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: When requesting media usage rights, Silverlight will provide the rights server with an ID for the DRM-protected content file and basic data about your device, including data about the DRM components on your device such as their revision and security levels, and a unique identifier for your device.

sent: In some cases, accessing DRM-protected content will require an update to Silverlight or to the DRM components on your device.

Source.Name: match_377.csv
sent: The Microsoft server uses this identifier to return a unique DRM update for your device, which will then be installed by Silverlight.
